snippet: The $4 billion spent to influence the outcome of the midterms isn’t as big a problem as the post-election purpose of that spending.
abstract: Joe Nocera Op-Ed column submits unlimited campaign spending is not by itself a problem but post-election assumption that money confers political influence is; points out some are 'ideological givers,' who are motivated to get like-minded people elected, while others are 'transactional givers,' who donate because they expect something concrete in return; holds incessant fundraising and diminished voter confidence tied to big money are also politically damaging.
lead_paragraph: The $4 billion spent to influence the outcome of the midterms isn’t as big a problem as the post-election purpose of that spending.

headline.main: Big Money Wins Again in a Romp
headline.print_headline: Big Money Wins Again in a Romp
